classes.title: PHCO154
classes.subtitle: PRIN PHCO/TOXICOL.  2 Credits.

classes.subtitle: General Pharmacology.  2.5 Credits.

classes.subtitle: General Pharmacology.  2.5 Credits.
classes.description: All preceding courses in chemistry, biology, bacteriology, and physiology in the Pharmacy School curriculum or their equivalent. A course for pharmacy students. Drug pharmacodynamics of major drug classes and organ systems will be stressed.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO156
classes.subtitle: General Pharmacology.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: All preceding courses in chemistry, biology, bacteriology, and physiology in the Pharmacy School curriculum or their equivalent. A course for pharmacy students. Drug pharmacodynamics of major drug classes and organ systems will be stressed.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO156
classes.subtitle: General Pharmacology.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: A course for pharmacy students. Drug pharmacodynamics of major drug classes and organ systems will be stressed.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO158
classes.subtitle: FUND OF DRUG ACTION.  3 Credits.
classes.description: A course for pharmacy students. Drug pharmacodynamics of major drug classes and organ systems will be stressed.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO158
classes.subtitle: FUND OF DRUG ACTION.  3 Credits.

classes.title: PHCO643
classes.subtitle: Cell Structure, Function, and Growth Control I.  3 Credits.

classes.title: PHCO643
classes.subtitle: Cell Structure, Function, and Growth Control I.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Comprehensive introduction to cell structure, function, and transformation.Requisites: Prerequisite, undergraduate cell biology or biochemistry or permission of the instructor.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: CBIO�643, BIOC�643, PHYI�643.

classes.title: PHCO701
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Molecular Pharmacology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Comprehensive introduction to cell structure, function, and transformation.Requisites: Prerequisite, undergraduate cell biology or biochemistry or permission of the instructor.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: CBIO�643, BIOC�643, PHYI�643.

classes.title: PHCO701
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Molecular Pharmacology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. A first-year pharmacology course outlining the basics of molecular pharmacology, including molecular biology, drug and receptor interactions, receptors and ion channels, regulation of second messengers, and drug metabolism. Three lecture hours a week.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO702
classes.subtitle: Principles of Pharmacology and Physiology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. A first-year pharmacology course outlining the basics of molecular pharmacology, including molecular biology, drug and receptor interactions, receptors and ion channels, regulation of second messengers, and drug metabolism. Three lecture hours a week.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO702
classes.subtitle: Principles of Pharmacology and Physiology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Introduces students to the major areas of pharmacology and physiology and serves as a basis for more advanced courses. Three lecture hours a week.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: TOXC�702.

classes.title: PHCO705
classes.subtitle: Behavioral Pharmacology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Introduces students to the major areas of pharmacology and physiology and serves as a basis for more advanced courses. Three lecture hours a week.Requisites: Prerequisite, CHEM�430; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: TOXC�702.

classes.title: PHCO705
classes.subtitle: Behavioral Pharmacology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Basic principles of pharmacology and behavior analysis are considered in relation to drugs that affect the central nervous system.Requisites: Prerequisite, PSYC�404; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: PSYC�705, NBIO�705.

classes.title: PHCO707
classes.subtitle: Advanced Toxicology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Basic principles of pharmacology and behavior analysis are considered in relation to drugs that affect the central nervous system.Requisites: Prerequisite, PSYC�404; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: PSYC�705, NBIO�705.

classes.title: PHCO707
classes.subtitle: Advanced Toxicology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Cellular and physiological basis of toxicity of environmental chemicals, with emphasis on inhalation toxicology, developmental toxicology, immunotoxicology, radiation toxicology, renal toxicology, and neurotoxicology. Three lecture hours per week.Requisites: Prerequisite, PHCO�702; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: TOXC�707, ENVR�707.

classes.title: PHCO710
classes.subtitle: Cell Membranes.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Cellular and physiological basis of toxicity of environmental chemicals, with emphasis on inhalation toxicology, developmental toxicology, immunotoxicology, radiation toxicology, renal toxicology, and neurotoxicology. Three lecture hours per week.Requisites: Prerequisite, PHCO�702; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: TOXC�707, ENVR�707.

classes.title: PHCO710
classes.subtitle: Cell Membranes.  2 Credits.

classes.title: PHCO715
classes.subtitle: The Molecular Pharmacology of Cancer.  2 Credits.

classes.title: PHCO715
classes.subtitle: The Molecular Pharmacology of Cancer.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, advanced graduate or advanced undergraduate courses in biochemistry and molecular biology. This course deals with the molecular and cellular basis of anticancer and antiviral chemotherapy, with emphasis on novel approaches including immunotherapy, antisense oligonucleotides, and gene therapy. The course includes faculty lectures and student presentations.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO721
classes.subtitle: Seminar Courses in Pharmacology.  1-3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, advanced graduate or advanced undergraduate courses in biochemistry and molecular biology. This course deals with the molecular and cellular basis of anticancer and antiviral chemotherapy, with emphasis on novel approaches including immunotherapy, antisense oligonucleotides, and gene therapy. The course includes faculty lectures and student presentations.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO721
classes.subtitle: Seminar Courses in Pharmacology.  1-3 Credits.
classes.description: This is a series of seminar courses dealing with advanced topics in modern molecular pharmacology based mainly on discussion of current literature.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO722
classes.subtitle: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology I.  2-6 Credits.
classes.description: This is a series of seminar courses dealing with advanced topics in modern molecular pharmacology based mainly on discussion of current literature.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO722
classes.subtitle: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology I.  2-6 Credits.
classes.description: Lecture/discussion course on the physiology, pharmacology, biochemistry, and molecular biology of the nervous system. Topics include function and structure of ion channels, neurotransmitter biosynthesis and release mechanisms, neurotransmitter receptors, and intracellular signaling pathways.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO722
classes.subtitle: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology: Introduction and Electrical Signaling.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Lecture/discussion course on the physiology, pharmacology, biochemistry, and molecular biology of the nervous system. Topics include function and structure of ion channels, neurotransmitter biosynthesis and release mechanisms, neurotransmitter receptors, and intracellular signaling pathways.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO722
classes.subtitle: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology: Introduction and Electrical Signaling.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department. This course explores the experimental and theoretical function of the nervous system. Typically, the first hour is fundamental material presentation and the second hour may be a presentation led by the students. Topics covered include: cellular diversity in the CNS, gross brain anatomy, human and rodent brain imaging, neuromolecular genetics, behavioral methods, membrane potentials/resistance/capacitance, ion channel structure, electrophysiology and propagation of electrical signals in neurons. Basic undergraduate biology, chemistry, physics and intro calculus is assumed.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: NBIO�722A, BIOC�722A.

classes.title: PHCO722
classes.subtitle: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology: Postsynaptic Mechanisms-Receptors.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department. This course explores the experimental and theoretical function of the nervous system. Typically, the first hour is fundamental material presentation and the second hour may be a presentation led by the students. Topics covered include: cellular diversity in the CNS, gross brain anatomy, human and rodent brain imaging, neuromolecular genetics, behavioral methods, membrane potentials/resistance/capacitance, ion channel structure, electrophysiology and propagation of electrical signals in neurons. Basic undergraduate biology, chemistry, physics and intro calculus is assumed.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: NBIO�722A, BIOC�722A.

classes.title: PHCO722
classes.subtitle: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology: Postsynaptic Mechanisms-Receptors.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department. Consideration of membrane receptor molecules activated by neurotransmitters in the nervous system with emphasis on ligand binding behavior and molecular and functional properties of different classes of receptors. Course meets for four weeks with six lecture hours per week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: NBIO�722B, BIOC�722B.

classes.title: PHCO724
classes.subtitle: Ras Superfamily Proteins and Signal Transduction.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the department. Consideration of membrane receptor molecules activated by neurotransmitters in the nervous system with emphasis on ligand binding behavior and molecular and functional properties of different classes of receptors. Course meets for four weeks with six lecture hours per week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: NBIO�722B, BIOC�722B.

classes.title: PHCO724
classes.subtitle: Ras Superfamily Proteins and Signal Transduction.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Seminar/discussion course covering recent advances in the role of these proteins in signaling and growth.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO725
classes.subtitle: Signal Transduction.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Seminar/discussion course covering recent advances in the role of these proteins in signaling and growth.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO725
classes.subtitle: Signal Transduction.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Seminar/discussion course on molecular aspects of the receptors, G-proteins, effector proteins, kinases, and phosphatases that mediate hormone, neurotransmitter, growth factor, and sensory signaling.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOC�725.

classes.title: PHCO726
classes.subtitle: Adhesion Receptors and Signaling in Cancer and CV Disease.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Seminar/discussion course on molecular aspects of the receptors, G-proteins, effector proteins, kinases, and phosphatases that mediate hormone, neurotransmitter, growth factor, and sensory signaling.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOC�725.

classes.title: PHCO726
classes.subtitle: Adhesion Receptors and Signaling in Cancer and CV Disease.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Examines the growing number of families of cell adhesion receptors and their role in biological processes including signal transduction, control of gene expression, hemostasis, cancer, neuronal development, immunobiology, and embryologic development.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO727
classes.subtitle: Structure and Function of Ion Channels.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Examines the growing number of families of cell adhesion receptors and their role in biological processes including signal transduction, control of gene expression, hemostasis, cancer, neuronal development, immunobiology, and embryologic development.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO727
classes.subtitle: Structure and Function of Ion Channels.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Seminar/discussion course on the physiology, pharmacology, biochemistry, and molecular biology of ion channel proteins.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO728
classes.subtitle: Neuropharmacology of Alcohol and Substance Abuse.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Seminar/discussion course on the physiology, pharmacology, biochemistry, and molecular biology of ion channel proteins.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO728
classes.subtitle: Neuropharmacology of Alcohol and Substance Abuse.  3 Credits.
classes.description: A lecture/discussion course on the biological bases of alcohol and substance abuse.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO729
classes.subtitle: Gene Therapy: Medicine for the 21st Century.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A lecture/discussion course on the biological bases of alcohol and substance abuse.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO729
classes.subtitle: Gene Therapy: Medicine for the 21st Century.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A seminar/discussion course on recent advances in targeted gene delivery and gene therapy.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO730
classes.subtitle: Seminar in Recent Advances in Pharmacology.  1 Credit.
classes.description: A seminar/discussion course on recent advances in targeted gene delivery and gene therapy.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO730
classes.subtitle: Seminar in Recent Advances in Pharmacology.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Students meet as a group with faculty members to develop skills in critical reading and to summarize and discuss selected aspects of current pharmacological literature. Two hours a week. Fall and spring.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO731
classes.subtitle: Recent Advances in the Pharmacological Sciences.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Students meet as a group with faculty members to develop skills in critical reading and to summarize and discuss selected aspects of current pharmacological literature. Two hours a week. Fall and spring.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO731
classes.subtitle: Recent Advances in the Pharmacological Sciences.  1 Credit.
classes.description: This graduate-level course encompasses both seminars presented by distinguished faculty from UNC, Duke, and other high-level research institutions, and seminars presented by students in the Pharmacological Sciences Training Program (PSTP) to other PSTP students and faculty. Students are required to attend at least 80% of these seminars each semester.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO732
classes.subtitle: Grant Writing.  2 Credits.
classes.description: This graduate-level course encompasses both seminars presented by distinguished faculty from UNC, Duke, and other high-level research institutions, and seminars presented by students in the Pharmacological Sciences Training Program (PSTP) to other PSTP students and faculty. Students are required to attend at least 80% of these seminars each semester.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO732
classes.subtitle: Grant Writing.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A discussion course covering the elements of successful grant proposals and scientific ethics.Requisites: Prerequisite, PHCO�701; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO733
classes.subtitle: Drug Discovery and Development.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A discussion course covering the elements of successful grant proposals and scientific ethics.Requisites: Prerequisite, PHCO�701; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO733
classes.subtitle: Drug Discovery and Development.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A seminar/discussion course on the research, development, and regulatory processes involved in bringing new drugs to clinical use.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO734
classes.subtitle: Pain and Analgesia.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A seminar/discussion course on the research, development, and regulatory processes involved in bringing new drugs to clinical use.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO734
classes.subtitle: Pain and Analgesia.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A lecture/discussion course on pain transmission and pain measurement. The neuropharmacological basis of pain modulation will be discussed.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO735
classes.subtitle: Discovery Biology and Pharmacogenomics.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A lecture/discussion course on pain transmission and pain measurement. The neuropharmacological basis of pain modulation will be discussed.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO735
classes.subtitle: Discovery Biology and Pharmacogenomics.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Lecture/discussion course covering a variety of aspects of new biological and computational technologies. The course is predominantly in a lecture format with computer-based and literature assignments.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO736
classes.subtitle: Protein Kinases as Targets for Novel Pharmacological Inhibitors.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Lecture/discussion course covering a variety of aspects of new biological and computational technologies. The course is predominantly in a lecture format with computer-based and literature assignments.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO736
classes.subtitle: Protein Kinases as Targets for Novel Pharmacological Inhibitors.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A seminar/discussion course to evaluate the use of small molecule inhibitors of protein kinases from a structural and signal transduction perspective.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO737
classes.subtitle: Target-Based Drug Discovery and Cancer Treatment.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A seminar/discussion course to evaluate the use of small molecule inhibitors of protein kinases from a structural and signal transduction perspective.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO737
classes.subtitle: Target-Based Drug Discovery and Cancer Treatment.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A lecture/discussion course that emphasizes preclinical and clinical studies for the development of anti-cancer drugs that target signal transduction. Topics include: target identification and validation, drug discovery, the process of government approval for clinical trials, design of clinical trials, and new genetic-based technologies to foster drug development.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO738
classes.subtitle: Nanomedicine.  2 Credits.
classes.description: A lecture/discussion course that emphasizes preclinical and clinical studies for the development of anti-cancer drugs that target signal transduction. Topics include: target identification and validation, drug discovery, the process of government approval for clinical trials, design of clinical trials, and new genetic-based technologies to foster drug development.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO738
classes.subtitle: Nanomedicine.  2 Credits.
classes.description: This course offers an introduction to the nascent interdisciplinary field of nanomedicine for students with physical/biological science backgrounds; course will be based on student led discussions of current literature.Requisites: Prerequisite, completion of undergraduate major in physical or biological science or permission of the instructor.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO739
classes.subtitle: Reprogramming of Somatic and Stem Cells and Its Applications in Pharmacology.  2 Credits.
classes.description: This course offers an introduction to the nascent interdisciplinary field of nanomedicine for students with physical/biological science backgrounds; course will be based on student led discussions of current literature.Requisites: Prerequisite, completion of undergraduate major in physical or biological science or permission of the instructor.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO739
classes.subtitle: Reprogramming of Somatic and Stem Cells and Its Applications in Pharmacology.  2 Credits.
classes.description: The objective of this new elective is to provide graduate students with an overview of stem cell biology with a unique emphasis on the applications of stem cells in pharmacology, particularly in areas of cancer and tissue regeneration.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO740
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: Phosphorylation Control.  1 Credit.
classes.description: The objective of this new elective is to provide graduate students with an overview of stem cell biology with a unique emphasis on the applications of stem cells in pharmacology, particularly in areas of cancer and tissue regeneration.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO740
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: Phosphorylation Control.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry, pharmacology and/or cell & molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. This graduate-level course is an in-depth analysis of how protein kinases and protein phosphorylation regulates key aspects of cell signaling. This class is one of the "Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling" modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO741
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: GTPases.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry, pharmacology and/or cell & molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. This graduate-level course is an in-depth analysis of how protein kinases and protein phosphorylation regulates key aspects of cell signaling. This class is one of the "Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling" modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO741
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: GTPases.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry, pharmacology, and/or cell & molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. This graduate-level course conveys principles of signal transduction controlled by GTPases and emphasizes in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. This class is one of the "Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling" modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO742
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: Cell Cycle Control.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry, pharmacology, and/or cell & molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. This graduate-level course conveys principles of signal transduction controlled by GTPases and emphasizes in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. This class is one of the "Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling" modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO742
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: Cell Cycle Control.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry and/or cell & molecular biology. This graduate-level course conveys principles of eukaryotic cell proliferation control emphasizing in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. This class is one of the Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO743
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: Signaling Networks.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Required preparation, coursework in biochemistry and/or cell & molecular biology. This graduate-level course conveys principles of eukaryotic cell proliferation control emphasizing in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. This class is one of the Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling modules.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO743
classes.subtitle: Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling: Signaling Networks.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Acquire the scientific vocabulary of the signaling network field. Master key concepts from mathematical characterization of signaling circuits. Develop and apply critical analysis skills.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOC�743.

classes.title: PHCO744
classes.subtitle: Topics on Stem Cells and Development.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Acquire the scientific vocabulary of the signaling network field. Master key concepts from mathematical characterization of signaling circuits. Develop and apply critical analysis skills.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOC�743.

classes.title: PHCO744
classes.subtitle: Topics on Stem Cells and Development.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in genetics, cell biology, and molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. Course addresses key issues in developmental biology focused on the role of stem cells and emphasizes in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. One of the Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling modules.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOC�744.

classes.title: PHCO745
classes.subtitle: Intercellular Signaling in Development and Disease.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Required preparation, coursework in genetics, cell biology, and molecular biology. Permission of the instructor. Course addresses key issues in developmental biology focused on the role of stem cells and emphasizes in-depth discussion of current literature and unanswered questions. One of the Contemporary Topics in Cell Signaling modules.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOC�744.

classes.title: PHCO745
classes.subtitle: Intercellular Signaling in Development and Disease.  1 Credit.
classes.description: This graduate-level course concentrates on up-to-date views of intercellular signal processing, with emphasis on signal transduction mechanisms as they relate to cellular/physiological responses in both normal development and disease. Signaling mechanisms that will be discussed include autocrine, paracrine, juxtacrine signaling and cell-matrix interactions.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOS�745.

classes.title: PHCO746
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Computer Vision Tools for Modern Microscopy.  1 Credit.
classes.description: This graduate-level course concentrates on up-to-date views of intercellular signal processing, with emphasis on signal transduction mechanisms as they relate to cellular/physiological responses in both normal development and disease. Signaling mechanisms that will be discussed include autocrine, paracrine, juxtacrine signaling and cell-matrix interactions.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOS�745.

classes.title: PHCO746
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Computer Vision Tools for Modern Microscopy.  1 Credit.
classes.description: This course will introduce computer vision methods for cell biology. Each topic will be motivated with an explanation of a computational challenge, followed by a discussion of available techniques to address the need and practical examples for how to apply the techniques.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO747
classes.subtitle: Biological Concepts.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: This course will introduce computer vision methods for cell biology. Each topic will be motivated with an explanation of a computational challenge, followed by a discussion of available techniques to address the need and practical examples for how to apply the techniques.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO747
classes.subtitle: Biological Concepts.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: Overview of structures and biological determinants of conditions and diseases of the oral cavity. Both growth and development and pathophysiology will be introduced in the context of three areas of oral biology: biology of extracellular matrices, host-pathogens interactions, and orofacial neurobiology.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: OCBM�732, NBIO�732.

classes.title: PHCO748
classes.subtitle: Translational Pain Medicine.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: Overview of structures and biological determinants of conditions and diseases of the oral cavity. Both growth and development and pathophysiology will be introduced in the context of three areas of oral biology: biology of extracellular matrices, host-pathogens interactions, and orofacial neurobiology.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: OCBM�732, NBIO�732.

classes.title: PHCO748
classes.subtitle: Translational Pain Medicine.  1.5 Credit.
classes.description: This is a clinician-taught course that advances students' understanding of chronic pain (e.g., head/face pain, pelvic pain, back pain, cancer pain, surgical pain) in both the classroom and the clinic.Requisites: Prerequisite, OBIO 732; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: OCBM�733.

classes.title: PHCO749
classes.subtitle: Practical RNA-Seq.  2 Credits.
classes.description: This is a clinician-taught course that advances students' understanding of chronic pain (e.g., head/face pain, pelvic pain, back pain, cancer pain, surgical pain) in both the classroom and the clinic.Requisites: Prerequisite, OBIO 732; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: OCBM�733.

classes.title: PHCO749
classes.subtitle: Practical RNA-Seq.  2 Credits.
classes.description: This course is designed to familiarize students with everything needed to run an RNA-Seq experiment. There will be minimal emphasis on theory and heavy focus on practical aspects. There are no formal prerequisites required for this course and no prior experience with UNIX or the command line interface is expected.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GNET�749.

classes.title: PHCO750
classes.subtitle: Proteomics Methods and Applications.  1 Credit.
classes.description: This course is designed to familiarize students with everything needed to run an RNA-Seq experiment. There will be minimal emphasis on theory and heavy focus on practical aspects. There are no formal prerequisites required for this course and no prior experience with UNIX or the command line interface is expected.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GNET�749.

classes.title: PHCO750
classes.subtitle: Proteomics Methods and Applications.  1 Credit.
classes.description: The goal of this course is to familiarize students with the fundamental concepts of proteomics and its applications to real-world biomedical research. Lectures will focus on the fundamentals of mass spectrometry and three broad proteomics applications: expression proteomics, post-translational modification identification/quantitation, and affinity proteomics. Practical aspects of these applications, such as rigorous experimental design, sample preparation and data interpretation will be emphasized throughout the lectures. Students will also get hands-on experience preparing samples for LC-MS/MS. This course is intended for 2nd year students and above who currently use or plan to use proteomics in their research.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO900
classes.subtitle: Special Pharmacology Research.  3-6 Credits.
classes.description: The goal of this course is to familiarize students with the fundamental concepts of proteomics and its applications to real-world biomedical research. Lectures will focus on the fundamentals of mass spectrometry and three broad proteomics applications: expression proteomics, post-translational modification identification/quantitation, and affinity proteomics. Practical aspects of these applications, such as rigorous experimental design, sample preparation and data interpretation will be emphasized throughout the lectures. Students will also get hands-on experience preparing samples for LC-MS/MS. This course is intended for 2nd year students and above who currently use or plan to use proteomics in their research.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: PHCO900
classes.subtitle: Special Pharmacology Research.  3-6 Credits.

classes.subtitle: Research in Pharmacology.  1-15 Credits.

classes.subtitle: Special Pharmacology Research.  3-6 Credits.
